ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learning how to apply the concepts and theory in class to relevant modern day materials. Recognize that there is always room to improve and build better models.

The course gives a varied insight into many of the models surrounding exchange rates, sudden stops, international business cycles, and other topics in international finance. We normally spent around two weeks on each subject going through the proposed model and its implications before moving on.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The material and design of the course was pretty fair. The only part was the transition from class and psets to the paper was not very clear. The objective of the paper could be better explained.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: International finance introduces very interesting concepts that build off of macroeconomics and focuses on models that pertain to finance. A pretty good advanced lecture with reasonable workload. Professor Huo is also very approachable. The paper is manageable, you just have to start early.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student looking for a seminar that builds on some of the subjects in their intermediate macro course. This course covers a lot of interesting topics at a good pace.
